item.title: No one wants Afghanistan to become breeding ground for terror - PM
item.description: Boris Johnson calls on "like-minded" powers to not recognise any new government without agreement.

item.title: Afghanistan conflict: Taliban push into Kabul as president flees
item.description: The militants are close to taking total control now that US-led forces have all but withdrawn.

item.title: Haiti earthquake: Rescuers search for survivors as death toll climbs to 700
item.description: More than 700 people are known to have died after a powerful earthquake hit the nation on Saturday.

item.title: Plymouth shooting: Prayers to remember victims
item.description: Father David Way says it is a time of "shock, sadness and horror" following the shootings.

item.title: Roger Federer will be out 'for many months' as he prepares for further knee surgery
item.description: Tennis great Roger Federer says he will be sidelined for "many months" as he prepares to have further knee surgery.

item.title: Olympics and Paralympics: GB athletes to get more government funds in run-up to Paris Games in 2024
item.description: The government will increase its funding of Great Britain's Olympians and Paralympians by £23.4m annually to £77.4m a year to aid preparation for the Paris Games in 2024.

item.title: Covid: 16 and 17-year-olds in England to be offered jab by 23 August
item.description: Those in England will be offered a jab or the chance to book one by 23 August, the government says.

item.title: Dead police officer and child in Kidderminster were father and son
item.description: Colleagues from the West Mercia force name the pair as David Louden, 39, and Harrison, three.

item.title: Esther Dingley: Hiker's partner thanks 'hero' searchers
item.description: Daniel Colegate pays tribute to French and Spanish teams who looked for his partner Esther Dingley.

item.title: Canada election: Trudeau calls snap summer campaign
item.description: As Prime Minister Justin Trudeau goes to the polls two years early, here's what you need to know.

item.title: Woman seriously injured by her dog in attack
item.description: She was injured when her American bulldog turned on a child then attacked her as she intervened.

item.title: Tottenham 1-0 Manchester City: Son Heung-min strike gives Spurs victory without Harry Kane
item.description: Son Heung-min's superb strike proves decisive as a Tottenham side without Harry Kane give new boss Nuno Espirito Santo a win over Premier League champions Manchester City.

item.title: Germany football legend Muller dies aged 75
item.description: Bayern Munich and Germany legend Gerd Muller dies at the age of 75.

item.title: Will Taliban take country back to past, asks John Simpson
item.description: What sort of nation will Afghanistan be after 2021, asks the BBC's world affairs editor John Simpson.

item.title: Afghanistan conflict: As Kabul falls, Biden backlash grows
item.description: Soldiers, statesmen and Afghan-Americans criticise the president - but how will the public react?

item.title: Afghanistan: People flee Kabul as Taliban overrun cities
item.description: Roads out of the Afghan capital have been choked with traffic as people try to escape a Taliban takeover.

item.title: Afghanistan: Taliban spokesman Suhail Shaheen calls the BBC - interview in full
item.description: A spokesman for the Taliban, Suhail Shaheen, called the BBC's Yalda Hakim, live on air.

item.title: Mapping the advance of the Taliban in Afghanistan
item.description: Maps of Afghanistan show who controls districts in fighting between the government and Taliban forces.

item.title: Afghan war: Kabul's young women plead for help as Taliban advance
item.description: They feel abandoned by the democratic world they thought they were part of, writes Yalda Hakim.

item.title: Afghanistan: Why is there a war?
item.description: As foreign forces pull out after 20 years of war, what did it achieve and what happens next?

item.title: Afghanistan: The people fleeing the north for safety in Kabul
item.description: The Taliban has taken new territories in the north, forcing thousands out of their homes.

item.title: Afghans living under Taliban lament loss of freedoms
item.description: Afghans in Taliban-controlled provinces describe life under its fundamentalist Islamist rule.

item.title: ‘Not an Afghanistan problem but a humanity problem’ - Gen McMaster
item.description: This is a frontier between barbarism and civilisation, a former US national security adviser says.

item.title: How do we slow down fast fashion?
item.description: The clothes we wear can have a huge impact on the climate, even more so than the aviation industry.

item.title: Cornwall rescue: Cat's meows alert rescuers to stricken owner
item.description: Piran the cat leads rescuers to its 83-year-old owner, who had fallen down a 70ft (21m) ravine.

item.title: A refugee puppet and meteor shower - stories you may have missed
item.description: We also travel back to the Ice Age and to Sao Paulo's tallest building in this week's round-up.

item.title: 'It's not just boys who can do it'
item.description: Girls take part in a summer scheme introducing them to careers traditionally viewed as jobs for men.

item.title: 'My sister's legacy is the Sibling Grief Club'
item.description: Sisters from County Tyrone started The Sibling Grief Club after their youngest sister died suddenly.

item.title: Afghanistan: Journalist Anisa Shaheed refuses to give in to Taliban
item.description: Anisa Shaheed fears women's freedoms will be curbed again if the Taliban come to power.

item.title: Sri Lankan teenager builds solar-powered tuk-tuk from scraps
item.description: Piranawan, 15, from Sri Lanka spent eight months of his Covid lockdown making his eco-friendly vehicle.

item.title: Boy takes on 150-mile walk from Rugby to visit grandparents
item.description: Fundraising Arthur Mortimer says he is looking forward to his nan's cakes after lockdown kept them apart.

item.title: The papers: Gun owners 'should face hate trawl' and Afghans flee
item.description: A call from a former Met Police chief to improve checks on prospective gun owners is among the front-page stories.

item.title: Humpback whale spotted off Pembrokeshire coast
item.description: Tour guide Ffion Rees says it is the first time she had seen the species in UK waters in 27 years.

item.title: Newcastle tyre-flipping world records attempted
item.description: The organisers plan teams and individual attempts using large car and tractor tyres.

item.title: 'How I found out my dad was a best-selling sex writer'
item.description: Sara Faith Alterman was always close to her father. Then she learned he was concealing a secret.

item.title: Who is TikTok’s masked vigilante?
item.description: Think you’re safe being an anonymous TikTok troll or cyber bully? Meet your worst nightmare.

item.title: 'My night in notorious Nazi collaborator Quisling's cabin'
item.description: When Ben McPherson realised he could rent Vidkun Quisling's cabin, it struck him as weird. His Norwegian wife disagreed.

item.title: 'This was a race and we lost': How US doctors really feel about Covid surge
item.description: Healthcare workers react to the growing rise of Covid patients in US hospitals despite vaccines.

item.title: Ethiopia: What do we know about aid going into Tigray?
item.description: Who's preventing desperately needed aid supplies reaching Ethiopia's Tigray region?

item.title: Sarah Rainsford on Russia: 'I've been told I can't come back - ever'
item.description: The BBC's Sarah Rainsford, devastated after being told she could not return to Russia, ever.

item.title: Shetland’s biggest gig – the day Pulp flew in to Lerwick
item.description: At the height of their fame, the Britpop icons travelled to Lerwick to play a show for just 1,400 fans.

item.title: Will I ever be able to fly without feeling guilty again?
item.description: More efficient planes and sustainable fuels could lower air travel's impact, but not for a while.

item.title: Late England burst sets up final-day thriller
item.description: The second Test is set for a grandstand finale after England make late inroads into the India batting on the fourth day at Lord's.

item.title: England v India: Second Test finely poised after late wickets for England at Lord's
item.description: Watch highlights as England take three wickets for 20 runs to leave India 181-6, 154 ahead, with all four results possible on the final day of the second Test at Lord's.

item.title: Tottenham 1-0 Manchester City: Nuno Espirito Santo 'very proud' of Spurs after opening win
item.description: Nuno Espirito Santo says it was a “good day” for Tottenham Hotspur as they opened their Premier League season with a 1-0 win over Manchester City.

item.title: La Liga highlights: Barcelona start life after Messi with win over Real Sociedad
item.description: Barcelona began life without Lionel Messi by scoring four goals and beating Real Sociedad in an entertaining La Liga opener.

item.title: Barca edge out Real Sociedad in first game of post-Messi era
item.description: Barcelona begin life without Lionel Messi with a win over Real Sociedad in their La Liga opener.

item.title: Covid: What do under-30s need to know about the vaccine?
item.description: The government has announced that 16 and 17-year-olds will receive the Covid vaccine.

item.title: ‘Covid passport’: How to prove your vaccine status with the NHS Covid Pass
item.description: Fully vaccinated adults will be able to avoid self-isolation after contact with someone with Covid.

item.title: Covid: Who has to self-isolate, which workers are exempt and what if I'm fully vaccinated?
item.description: The rules in England and Northern Ireland will change from Monday 16 August.

item.title: What are the travel rules for Spain, Portugal, Malta and other holiday hotspots?
item.description: What you need to know about going to Portugal, Spain, Greece, France, Malta, Italy and Turkey.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid rules: What's changing in Wales, Scotland, England and Northern Ireland?
item.description: Lockdown rules are changing across the UK, but some restrictions remain in place.

item.title: Covid: What will school be like in the new term?
item.description: Pupils across the UK are preparing to return to school after the summer holidays.

item.title: Coronavirus: What do we know about the artemisia plant?
item.description: Artemisia plant extracts have anti-malarial properties, but there's no evidence they can combat Covid-19.

item.title: UK holidays: What are the rules?
item.description: Going abroad is not straightforward, so many people are opting to stay in the UK for their holidays.

item.title: Covid: How do I get a lateral flow or PCR test?
item.description: Everyone in England and Scotland is being encouraged to take rapid coronavirus tests regularly.

item.title: What are the rules and guidance for face masks and coverings?
item.description: Masks are no longer compulsory in England, but remain necessary in other parts of the UK.

item.title: Wildfires: How Portuguese club Tondela drove through the flames
item.description: In Tondela, the bond between club and fans was at its strongest during the night in October 2017 when nobody slept.

item.title: Malta: The teenagers pulled from the sea and accused of terrorism
item.description: How three teenagers rescued from the Mediterranean Sea ended up in Malta accused of terrorism.

item.title: ‘If only I’d found out earlier I had pelvic congestion syndrome’
item.description: Sophie Robehmed suffered from back and stomach pains for years before being diagnosed with PCS.
